docs.snippet: Carlos Beltran made his career debut at first base Sunday night and recorded three hits, including a two-run home run, to help the Yankees to a 3-2 win....
docs.lead_paragraph: Carlos Beltran made his career debut at first base Sunday night and recorded three hits, including a two-run home run, to help the Yankees to a 3-2 win.
docs.abstract: New York Yankees beat Boston Red Sox, 3-2, as Carlos Beltran makes his career debut at first base.

headline.main: Yankees Find Another First Baseman in a Pinch, Then Beat Boston
headline.print_headline: Yankees Find Another First Baseman in a Pinch, Then Beat Boston

docs.snippet: Jacoby Ellsbury has done well when third in the order — the spot of Ruth, Mantle, Mattingly and O’Neill — but he is known more for scoring runs than for driving them in....
docs.lead_paragraph: Jacoby Ellsbury has done well when third in the order — the spot of Ruth, Mantle, Mattingly and O’Neill — but he is known more for scoring runs than for driving them in.
docs.abstract: Benjamin Hoffman Keeping Score column examines Jacob Ellsbury's performance batting third for the New York Yankees, spot that has been occupied by some of team's greatest players; argues that while Ellsbury has done well so far, his nature as a run-scorer makes him an odd choice for the slot.

headline.main: Ellsbury Batting Third for Yankees Without Fitting Profile
headline.print_headline: Ellsbury, a Leadoff Man Batting Third

docs.snippet: The Brewers (10-2) are off to their best start since going 13-0 to start the 1987 season. It is Milwaukee’s longest winning streak since a nine-game string last April....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Brewers (10-2) are off to their best start since going 13-0 to start the 1987 season. It is Milwaukee’s longest winning streak since a nine-game string last April.
docs.abstract: MLB Roundup; Milwaukee Brewers beat Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-1, their ninth consecutive victory; other baseball news noted.

headline.main: Behind Gem From Lohse, Brewers Win 9th in a Row

docs.snippet: Tony Perez was on the road with the Cincinnati Reds in 1966 when he got the call that his first child was on the way. There was no discussion about leaving the team to attend Victor's birth, no such thing as paternity leave....
docs.lead_paragraph: Tony Perez was on the road with the Cincinnati Reds in 1966 when he got the call that his first child was on the way. There was no discussion about leaving the team to attend Victor's birth, no such thing as paternity leave.

headline.main: Pro Sports Becoming More Open to Paternity Leave
headline.print_headline: Pro Sports Becoming More Open to Paternity Leave
